texts.shortText:
Members of this family are dorso-ventrally flattened and have powerful legs held spread out laterally to grip the substratum. The second antennae are large, robust and sometimes brightly-coloured. The second pair of claws (gnathopod 2) are very large and powerful. The abdomen is held curled under the body and urosome segment 1 is unusually elongated (more than twice as long as segment 2). The second pair of uropods may be reduced and the third pair either reduced or completely absent.

This species has a smooth body lacking any dorsal projections and is pale, mottled brown in colour. Distinctive combs of spines along the inner branches of the large uropods1 and 2 distinguish it from other local species. It is also easily identified by its unique habitat within the body cavities of the large ascidian Pyura spolonifera (Redbait).

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Currently known only from False Bay, but poorly studied and probably much more widespread, as the host occurs along most of the coast.

Fairly recently discovered species that is known only from the branchial cavities of the large ascidian or redbait, Pyura stolonifera. Seldom observed but limited sampling suggests that most ascidians harbour 1-2 individual amphipods just inside the entrances to the siphons.
Presumed to capture food items from the water stream pumped by the ascidian, using the setose second antennae.

As with all amphipods, sexes are separate. The eggs are extruded into a marsupial chamber beneath the legs of females, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully formed young before being released.

There are about 10 described regional species in this family and several other undescribed ones that have been photographed, but this species is unique in terms of its habitat within ascidians. Morphologically the strongly spinose uropods and lack of dorsal projections on the body are also useful identification features.

Griffiths, CL (1975). The Amphipoda of southern Africa: part 5. The Gammaridea and Caprellidea of the Cape Province west of Cape Agulhas. Annals of the South African Museum, 67 (5), 91-181 (p. 164)

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 41).
